study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and mechanisms of a physiotherapist-delivered, combined physical and psychological intervention (BOOST programme) on disability in people with neurogenic claudication from spinal stenosis, with walking capacity as the primary mechanism of interest.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a planned secondary analysis to estimate the mechanistic effects of the BOOST programme on disability, focusing on walking capacity and other secondary mediators like fear-avoidance behavior and walking self-efficacy, with outcomes measured at 12 months.
population_specificity: Older people with neurogenic claudication from spinal stenosis.
study_duration: 6 months for mediator measurement, 12 months for outcome measurement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of environmental and behavioral interventions (including exercise programs) in reducing physical activity limitation, preventing falls, and improving quality of life among visually impaired older adults.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of effect for most environmental or behavioral interventions in reducing physical activity limitation or preventing falls, with low-certainty evidence due to methodological limitations and heterogeneous outcome measurements. Some trials showed modest reductions in fall risk, but results were inconsistent and not clinically significant.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 80 years, 69% female) with irreversible visual impairment, living in their own homes or residential settings.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included exercise programs and home safety modifications).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 2 to 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multi-component workplace interventions targeting physical activity (iPA) or sedentary behavior (iSED) could increase device-measured physical activity or reduce sedentary behavior compared to a control group.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (%MVPA) or sedentary behavior (%Sedentary) between the intervention groups (iPA, iSED) and the control group after 6 months. Both interventions were unsuccessful in achieving their intended outcomes.
population_specificity: Office workers (73% women, mean age 42 ± 9 years) from two companies, excluding those with very high baseline physical activity levels.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included cognitive behavioral therapy counseling, gym access, and encouragement for physical activity or reduced sitting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined cognitive-motor virtual reality training improves dual-task gait speed and information processing speed in individuals with Multiple Sclerosis compared to conventional treadmill training.
results_summary: The study anticipates that virtual reality-enhanced treadmill training will significantly improve dual-task gait speed and information processing speed more than treadmill training alone, though final results are pending.
population_specificity: 144 individuals with Multiple Sclerosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of nurse-driven self-management programs, including walking (measured via 6MWD), on physical and psychosocial health in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking distance (6MWD) and physical health scores (CAT) in COPD patients following nurse-driven self-management programs. Psychosocial health also improved, with increased quality of life and reduced anxiety/depression scores (HADS).
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of upfront triple combination therapy (uTCT) in pediatric pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), including its impact on 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that uTCT in pediatric PAH patients showed significant clinical improvement, including potential benefits in 6-minute walking distance, though specific results for walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children diagnosed with PAH between 2010 and 2019.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness and safety of ivacaftor in patients with severe CF carrying residual function mutations.
results_summary: The study found that ivacaftor treatment resulted in a clinically significant improvement in lung function, evident at 1 month and maintained at 12 months, with no significant safety concerns reported.
population_specificity: Patients with severe CF carrying residual function mutations enrolled in an ivacaftor compassionate use program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a 6-month walking exercise program for patients undergoing chemotherapy and evaluate its effects on glycemic control and symptom severity.
results_summary: The study found that the walking program was feasible, with most participants completing the 6-month intervention. The intervention group showed a slight decrease in glycosylated hemoglobin A1c and significantly less sleep disturbance and depression compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Predominantly non-Hispanic White female patients with breast cancer, normal-to-slightly-overweight BMI, undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of multiple versus single doses of dexamethasone on postoperative pain and complications in patients undergoing unicompartmental knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study recorded CRP, IL-6, VAS pain scores at rest and walking, nausea VAS scores, and incidence of POVN at 24, 48, and 72 hours postoperatively, but specific results regarding walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (n=80).
effective_dosage: Study group: 20 mg dexamethasone IV post-anesthesia and repeated at 24 hours; control group: 10 mg dexamethasone IV post-anesthesia and repeated at 24 hours.
study_duration: Intervention administered at anesthesia and 24 hours post-surgery; outcomes measured up to 72 hours postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of iron therapy in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) and iron deficiency (ID), including its impact on exercise capacity (measured by 6MWT distance) and quality of life.
results_summary: Iron therapy improved 6-minute walking test (6MWT) distance and quality of life in CHF patients with ID, but did not significantly reduce all-cause or cardiovascular death. It also reduced cardiovascular hospitalizations and improved cardiac function without increasing adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) and iron deficiency (ID), regardless of anemia status.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of walking (WALK) on power, force production, jump, and functional performance against plyometric exercise (PLYO) and traditional resistance training (RT) in older men.
results_summary: Walking showed minimal improvement in leg press one-repetition maximum (1-RM) (2.9 ± 13.7%) compared to PLYO and RT, with no significant improvements in jump height, power, or functional performance. It was less effective than PLYO and RT for enhancing strength and power-related outcomes.
population_specificity: Older men (69.5 ± 3.9 years, N = 14 in WALK group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of local infiltration analgesia (LIA) and its effects on functional outcomes, including walking, after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found that LIA resulted in lower pain scores at rest on postoperative days 1 and 2 compared to placebo, suggesting potential benefits for early mobility and functional recovery. Functional outcomes such as active range of motion and knee function were assessed, but specific walking-related results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 135 patients undergoing primary total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
study_duration: Assessed from postoperative day 1 to discharge (length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of dopaminergic (levodopa) and cholinergic (donepezil) therapies on gait, prefrontal cortex activity, and dual-task performance in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Levodopa decreased prefrontal cortex activity, while donepezil reversed this effect. Combined donepezil and levodopa improved gait speed, stride length, and dual-task accuracy compared to off-medication conditions.
population_specificity: 19 Parkinson's disease patients.
effective_dosage: Donepezil 5 mg/day, levodopa dosage not specified.
study_duration: 2 weeks per treatment with a 2-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exercise (including walking) on physical function, fitness, activity, and psychological well-being in older patients with colorectal cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found low-level evidence for small beneficial effects of exercise on self-reported physical function and quality of life, and a moderate effect on reducing fatigue, but no evidence for benefits on physical fitness. Exercise was deemed feasible and safe with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Older patients (mean age 58.5 years) with colorectal cancer undergoing chemotherapy, excluding those with comorbidities or walking impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of alternative exercise modes (e.g., cycling, resistance training) with supervised walking exercise on walking distance and pain-free walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found no clear differences between alternative exercise modes and supervised walking in improving maximum or pain-free walking distance, with low-certainty evidence due to small sample sizes and clinical inconsistency. Alternative exercise modes may be useful when supervised walking is not feasible.
population_specificity: Patients with clinically determined intermittent claudication (527 participants across 10 studies).
effective_dosage: Supervised walking at least twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a cognitive-behavioral intervention ("Step by Step") improved fall-related self-efficacy and physical activity (measured by daily walking duration) in geriatric hip and pelvic fracture patients during and after inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved fall-related self-efficacy and secondary outcomes like perceived ability to manage falls and physical performance but did not increase daily walking duration compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Geriatric hip and pelvic fracture patients (mean age 82.5 years, 70% female) admitted to inpatient rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Eight individual sessions during rehabilitation, one home visit, and four telephone calls over 2 months post-discharge.
study_duration: Inpatient rehabilitation period plus 2 months post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether pretreatment with transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation (TEAS) could improve recovery from postoperative ileus (POI) in patients undergoing laparoscopic colon surgery.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results regarding Walking, as it focused on TEAS effects on POI recovery metrics such as time to first defaecation, flatus, and independent walking.
population_specificity: ASA physical status classification I-III level patients, aged 18-75 years, scheduled for laparoscopic colon surgery.
effective_dosage: Two sessions of TEAS/STEAS daily for 3 days before surgery, with a final treatment 30 min before anesthesia.
study_duration: 3 days pretreatment plus final session before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient-reported and functional outcomes between traditional cast immobilization and functional rehabilitation using a walking boot for nonoperative treatment of Achilles tendon rupture.
results_summary: Patients treated with a walking boot reported better functional outcomes (SMFA dysfunction index) at 6 months compared to those in a cast, though with a higher incidence of minor skin complications. Functional rehabilitation with early weightbearing was deemed a safe alternative to traditional immobilization.
population_specificity: 140 patients with acute Achilles tendon rupture (median age ~41 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention involved use of a walking boot or cast).
study_duration: 8 weeks for walking boot, 10 weeks for cast.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key factors influencing peak aerobic capacity in subacute stroke patients, including walking capacity, balance function, body composition, and lower limb strength.
results_summary: The study found that paretic isometric extensor strength, fat mass, and gait velocity (10MWV) were significantly correlated with peak aerobic capacity in subacute stroke patients. Walking capacity (measured by 10MWV) was a notable determinant of cardiovascular fitness.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (83 participants, mean age 62.95 ± 13.9 years, 47 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, safety, and preliminary efficacy of combining frontal lobe tDCS with complex walking rehabilitation for improving walking and executive function in older adults.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible and safe, with low side effects. All groups showed gains in walking performance, with the Sham/Typical group demonstrating the greatest improvements. The Active/Complex group showed the most significant gains in executive function, supported by moderate to large effect sizes.
population_specificity: Older adults
effective_dosage: Active tDCS was delivered at 2 mA intensity for 20 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the clinical effects of whole-body vibration training (WBVT) on physical capacity, proinflammatory cytokines, and myostatin in patients with fibrotic interstitial lung disease (ILD).
results_summary: WBVT significantly increased the 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and decreased myostatin levels in ILD patients, while the control group showed no significant changes. The study suggests WBVT is a beneficial and feasible training modality for this population.
population_specificity: Patients with multidisciplinary-confirmed fibrotic ILDs (n=26, 55-60% male, aged 61-63 years).
effective_dosage: 3 times per week on a GalileoTM vibration plate (6-20 Hz for WBVT, 5 Hz for sham training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of pedaling exercises on stiff-knee gait in post-stroke hemiparetic patients from a kinesiophysiological perspective.
results_summary: The pedaling group showed significant reductions in rectus femoris activity, increased knee and hip flexion angles and velocities, and improved step length and gait velocity on the paralyzed side. These changes suggest pedaling exercises can enhance gait ability in patients with stiff-knee gait post-stroke.
population_specificity: 21 patients with chronic post-stroke hemiparesis and stiff-knee gait.
effective_dosage: Pedaling at 5 Nm load and 40 rpm for 10 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the clinical meaning of a 3-level functional ambulation classification for polio survivors by comparing physical mobility status across categories and examining its relation to functional ambulation.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in walked distance, energy cost, and self-reported physical function between household walkers and limited community walkers, as well as between limited and community walkers, supporting the classification's clinical relevance.
population_specificity: 140 individuals with polio (mean age 59.4 years, 74 men) who could walk at least indoors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and synthesize literature on illness perceptions in patients with peripheral arterial disease, focusing on how these perceptions influence disease management and treatment adherence.
results_summary: The study found diverse illness perceptions among patients, including misunderstandings about the chronic nature of the disease, varied beliefs about control and cures (e.g., walking's impact), and fears about disease progression. An additional component highlighted the process of adapting to living with the disease.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of fear of falling (FOF) and fear-related activity restriction (FAR) and their association with frailty, sarcopenia, gait speed, grip strength, cognitive impairment, depression, social isolation, self-perceived health, and vision in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that FOF was highly prevalent (69.2%) among community-dwelling older adults, with 38.4% of those experiencing FAR. FOF was significantly associated with prefrailty/frailty, depression, number of medications, and female sex, while FOF+FAR was linked to depression and sarcopenia.
population_specificity: 493 community-dwelling older adults aged 60 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pulmonary rehabilitation (PR), which includes walking, for improving functional capacity and quality of life in patients with pneumoconiosis.
results_summary: PR significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, various health survey scores, lung function parameters, and quality of life metrics, with no reported adverse events. However, results should be interpreted cautiously due to high heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Patients with pneumoconiosis (1307 subjects across 16 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of powered exoskeletons for over-ground walking in Veterans with spinal cord injury (SCI) in home and community environments through a randomized clinical trial (RCT).
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results but highlights the challenges and rationale for conducting an RCT on exoskeletal-assisted walking, focusing on avoiding selection bias, participant recruitment, training, and safety concerns.
population_specificity: Veterans with spinal cord injury (SCI) who are unable to ambulate.

study_goal: To examine the safety and effectiveness of extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) for reducing pain and improving functionality in people with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: ESWT was found to significantly reduce pain (measured by VAS) and improve functionality (measured by WOMAC) in patients with KOA, with medium energetic density showing greater effects. The treatment had few minor side effects.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (n = 782 participants and 877 knees).
effective_dosage: Medium energetic density (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether 'soft' mobility management interventions (including promoting walking) could prevent, reduce, or delay car driving in teenagers aged 15 to 19 years and reduce crashes caused by teenage drivers.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence that educational interventions might reduce the likelihood of obtaining a driving license, but no direct measurements of walking's effects on driving frequency or alternative transport use were reported. The evidence was limited by small sample sizes, high risks of bias, and missing data.
population_specificity: Teenagers aged 15 to 19 years, including university students (mean age 18) and high school students (aged 17-18).
study_duration: Follow-up periods included 18 months (RCT) and 8 weeks (CBA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the tolerability and preliminary efficacy of dalfampridine (4-AP) on walking ability, endurance, and EMG in adult ambulatory SMA patients.
results_summary: Dalfampridine was safe and well-tolerated but showed no statistically significant positive effects on the primary functional motor outcome (6MWT distance, fatigue). It had positive effects on H-reflex and H/M ratio but not on CMAP amplitude.
population_specificity: Adult ambulatory SMA patients (mean age 37.7 ± 11.9 years, 54.5% male).
study_duration: Short-term (2 weeks) and long-term (6 weeks) treatment arms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dual-task training (walking combined with cognitive or motor tasks) versus single-task training (walking alone) on gait parameters, cognitive function, and quality of life in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Dual-task training improved gait velocity and stride length across all conditions and enhanced perceived quality of life, while single-task training only improved outcomes in the motor condition without affecting quality of life. Cognitive performance did not significantly change, though the dual-task group showed a trend toward better executive function.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stage I-III, mean age 66.72 years).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions, 1 hour each, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate risk factors for mobility impairment (poor gait speed) in patients newly starting dialysis and track changes in gait speed over a 2-year period.
results_summary: The study found that lower health utility, grip strength, diabetic nephropathy, and walking aid use were associated with slower baseline gait speed. Over 2 years, 54.2% of participants continued to lose gait speed, with age, walking aid use, lower health utility, and weaker handgrip strength being significant predictors of decline.
population_specificity: Incident dialysis patients (within 6 months of dialysis initiation), average age 54.7 years, 52.5% men, 73.9% black.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study assessed natural gait speed, not an intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of electromechanically assisted gait training (Exowalk®) versus conventional physiotherapy on walking ability in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvement in walking ability, but there was no significant difference between electromechanically assisted training and conventional physiotherapy. Secondary outcomes like walking speed, capacity, muscle strength, and balance also improved similarly in both groups.
population_specificity: Forty patients with hemiplegia after chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare early clinical results and survival between internal fixation and hip replacement for proximal femoral metastasis, focusing on walking capacity and complications.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in recovery of normal walking capacity between hip replacement and nailing, with better outcomes after preventive surgery. Complications were higher with plate fixation, but survival rates were comparable across techniques.
population_specificity: Patients with proximal femoral metastasis (182 females, 117 males, mean age 67.2±11.5 and 62.5±13.2 years, respectively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize qualitative research on experiences and perceptions of group walking to develop a new conceptual understanding of the group walking experience.
results_summary: The study found that group walking provides health and fitness benefits, fosters social connections, and transforms into a meaningful communal practice, though accessibility varies. Participants reported improved wellbeing, purpose, and confidence through shared walking experiences.
population_specificity: Walking groups in the UK, USA, Australia, and Ireland, including some for people with shared disease experiences or disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent data on the impact of chronic idiopathic axonal polyneuropathy (CIAP) on walking capacity, balance, and daily activities.
results_summary: The study found that CIAP impairs walking capacity, disturbs balance, increases fall risk, and negatively impacts daily activities, with neuropathic pain present in about two-thirds of patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic idiopathic axonal polyneuropathy (CIAP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and feasibility of a 15-day protocol combining repetitive peripheral magnetic stimulation (rPMS) and intensive physical therapy for improving gait disturbance in chronic stroke patients with lower limb hemiparesis.
results_summary: The treatment protocol significantly improved walking speed, ambulation ability, and balance but showed no significant effects on endurance capacity, step length, or spasticity. No rPMS-related side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Seven hemorrhagic stroke patients (ages 50-78) with lower limb hemiparesis and gait disturbance (7-107 months post-stroke).
effective_dosage: rPMS applied at 20 Hz for 3 s followed by 27-s rest intervals, totaling 80 trains (4800 pulses) per session, plus 120 min of daily physical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize international guidelines on nonpharmacological and nonsurgical interventions, including walking, for osteoarthritis (OA) management.
results_summary: The study found that walking is a key core treatment for knee, hip, and hand OA, recommended regardless of age, disease severity, or comorbidities. Walking aids/devices are specifically advised for hip and knee OA.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (knee, hip, and hand).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cognitive task training improves walking and balancing abilities in stroke patients.
results_summary: Cognitive task training significantly improved balance (Berg Balance Scale) and gait ability (Timed Up and Go test) in stroke patients, while general task training showed no significant change in TUG scores.
population_specificity: Seventeen stroke patients (10 males, 7 females).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate factors, including walking time, that contribute to functional decline in elderly individuals with hand or hip/knee osteoarthritis over a year.
results_summary: Walking time was identified as a risk factor for hand functional decline, but the study did not establish a direct efficacy of walking as an intervention. Other factors like OA, anxiety, and grip strength also influenced functional outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 65-85 with or at risk of hand or hip/knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if video consultations with physiotherapists for knee osteoarthritis management are non-inferior to traditional face-to-face consultations in improving knee pain and physical function.
results_summary: The study compared video consultations to face-to-face physiotherapy for knee osteoarthritis, focusing on changes in knee pain and physical function at 3 and 9 months. Secondary outcomes included quality of life, therapeutic relationship, and healthcare usage, with non-inferiority assessed per protocol.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic knee pain consistent with knee osteoarthritis in Australia.
effective_dosage: Five consultations (30-45 minutes each) over 3 months, plus a home-based strengthening exercise program and physical activity plan.
study_duration: 3 months (primary endpoint), with follow-up at 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of closed reduction (CR) versus open reduction with Salter innominate osteotomy (OR/IO) for treating developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) in children aged 18 to 60 months.
results_summary: At 48 years of follow-up, 69% of hips survived after OR/IO compared to 50% after CR. In bilateral cases, younger age at reduction favored CR, while older age favored OR/IO, with both treatments providing substantial benefit over natural DDH progression.
population_specificity: Children aged 18 to 60 months with DDH.
study_duration: Follow-up to a minimum of 40 years post-reduction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and radiological outcomes of total hip arthroplasty (THA) in patients with peri-acetabular metastasis (PAM) and assess factors impacting patient survival.
results_summary: Pain was eliminated or reduced in 91% of patients, and 83% achieved normal or acceptable walking ability. However, complications included surgical site infections (11%), dislocations (3%), and a 7% mortality rate within three months.
population_specificity: Patients with PAM secondary to breast cancer (46%) or lung cancer (22%), mean age 62.7±10.5 years.
study_duration: Median survivorship was 19.5 months (23.7 months for breast cancer, 8.9 months for lung cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of patellar denervation on anterior knee pain and functional outcomes after total knee arthroplasty with patellar resurfacing.
results_summary: The study found that patellar denervation did not improve anterior knee pain or clinical outcomes compared to non-denervation, with slightly better results in the non-denervation group for pressure pain threshold and visual analog scale scores during walking and stair use.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for total knee arthroplasty with patellar resurfacing (mean age 72.7 years, 70.4% women, average BMI 31.4 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Yangxinshi (YXS) tablet could improve exercise tolerance and quality of life in patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) when combined with a standardized western medicine and exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation program.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes a study protocol rather than completed findings. The study will evaluate exercise capacity (via cardiopulmonary exercise test and 6-minute walking test) and secondary outcomes like symptom improvement and adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease (CHD) from 3 hospitals in China (N=90).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness of turmeric extracts (TEs) as a pain treatment for knee joint pain, not Walking.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Walking.
population_specificity: 68 individuals with mild/moderate knee joint pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess physical performance, falls, fragility fractures, and pharmacological therapy in post-menopausal women based on their risk of falling.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in physical performance (4-meter gait speed and unipedal stance time) among women at different fall-risk levels, with high-risk individuals showing pathological results in 93.9% and 99.2% of cases, respectively. Falls and fragility fractures were also correlated with higher fall risk.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal women aged >60 years referred to Osteoporosis and Bone Metabolism Outpatient Services in Italy.
study_duration: Data collected over a 3-year period (May 2016 to April 2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher doses of therapeutic exercise, specifically aerobic and stepping activity, improve walking recovery and quality of life in stroke patients during inpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that higher doses of exercise (DOSE1 and DOSE2) significantly improved walking endurance compared to usual care, with benefits retained up to one year poststroke. Both higher-dose groups showed clinically meaningful improvements in walking recovery and quality of life.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (n=75) in the early phase of recovery (1-4 weeks poststroke) from six Canadian inpatient rehabilitation units.
effective_dosage: Control: 1 hour, 5 days/week; DOSE1: 1 hour, 5 days/week (more than double the intensity of Control); DOSE2: 2 hours, 5 days/week (more than quadruple the intensity of Control).

study_goal: To determine whether ballistic resistance training is feasible, safe, and effective in improving muscle strength, power generation, and mobility in adults with neurologic conditions.
results_summary: Ballistic resistance training was found to be feasible and safe, with only one intervention-related adverse event reported. It improved strength and power generation in specific muscle groups and had a positive treatment effect on self-selected walking speed, though results for fastest comfortable walking speed were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Adults with neurologic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms and consequences of breathlessness in patients with combined heart failure and COPD, and evaluate strategies like walking aids to mitigate symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that breathlessness in advanced heart failure-COPD results from excessive breathing due to increased ventilatory drive and mechanical derangements, and suggested interventions like walking aids and rehabilitation to alleviate symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced cardiorespiratory disease, specifically combined heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a 6-month treadmill walking intervention versus social ballroom dancing in improving executive function in older adults at increased risk for Alzheimer's disease or related dementias.
results_summary: The study explored the relative efficacy of treadmill walking as an active control intervention but did not report specific results for walking alone; it focused on comparing it to social ballroom dancing for executive function improvement.
population_specificity: Older adults at increased risk for Alzheimer's disease or related dementias (determined by memory impairment screen or AD8 Dementia Screening Interview scores).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in walking velocity, step length, and cadence after repeated abobotulinumtoxinA (aboBoNT-A) injections in spastic lower limb muscles of patients with hemiparesis.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant and clinically meaningful improvements in walking velocity (0.08 to 0.10 m/s), step length (0.03 to 0.04 m/step), and cadence (3.9 to 6.2 steps/min) after four treatment cycles. More patients achieved unlimited community ambulator status (WV ≥0.8 m/s) across test conditions compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults (18-80 years) with spastic hemiparesis and gait dysfunction due to stroke or traumatic brain injury.
effective_dosage: Not specified (up to four treatment cycles).
study_duration: Up to four treatment cycles (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the economic burden of nonaccidental trauma (NAT) related femoral fractures versus accidental trauma (AT) related femoral fractures in children under one year of age.
results_summary: The study found that NAT-related femoral fractures resulted in longer hospital stays (78.9 vs. 36.7 hours) and higher hospital costs ($24,726 more) compared to AT-related fractures, with imaging charges being the most significant cost contributor. The incidence of NAT in children under one with femoral fractures was 46.6%.
population_specificity: Children under one year of age treated for femoral fractures at a Level 1 Pediatric Trauma Center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the utility of 14 different scoring algorithms for Allostatic Load (AL) in predicting health outcomes among older adults.
results_summary: The study analyzed data from 4477 participants to evaluate various AL scoring methods but did not report specific findings related to Walking.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50+ years from the Irish Longitudinal Study on Ageing (TILDA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the dynamic interaction of step synchronization to auditory stimuli (music and metronomes) at different tempi in persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and healthy controls, focusing on gait dynamics.
results_summary: The study found no group differences between PwMS and healthy controls, but higher gait dynamics (measured by alpha) when walking to music compared to metronomes and at higher tempi (+8%, +10%). This suggests better precision and adaptation when synchronizing steps to music and faster tempi.
population_specificity: 28 persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and 29 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effects of an mHealth intervention on cognitive function, physical frailty, walking time, and MVPA in older adults with cognitive frailty.
results_summary: The mHealth intervention significantly improved frailty reduction, walking time, step count, brisk walking time, peak cadence, and MVPA time in the intervention group, while cognitive function improved in both groups. The intervention was feasible with high compliance rates.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥60 years with cognitive frailty and physical inactivity (median age 71.0 years, 85% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an 11-week combined training program (cardiorespiratory, resistance, balance, and flexibility) on exercise intolerance in pediatric hematological malignancy (PedHM) patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in stair climbing, strength, and flexibility in both high and medium adherence groups, while walking endurance and balance improved only in the high adherence group. These results support the idea that exercise can enhance physical function and social inclusion prospects in PedHM patients.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with hematological malignancies (PedHM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess lower limb loading ability (LLLA) in ambulatory individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) to determine thresholds for independent and safe walking with or without a walking device.
results_summary: The study found that ambulatory individuals with SCI required an average LLLA of at least 79% of their bodyweight for independent walking with a device and 94-95% for independent walking without a device and no multiple falls. These thresholds showed moderate diagnostic properties for predicting independence and safety.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) who walk independently with or without a walking device.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a multidirectional walking program could improve physical function and quality of life in adults receiving hematopoietic stem cell transplants (HSCT).
results_summary: The walking program showed significant improvements in aerobic capacity, physical and functional well-being, and overall quality of life post-intervention, while the usual care group saw no significant changes. Effect sizes favored the walking group, and clinically important differences were exceeded.
population_specificity: Adults receiving autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplants (HSCT).
study_duration: Intervention administered during hospitalization, with assessments at admission, 3-5 days post-HSCT, and 30 days post-HSCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical significance of anterior-posterior displacement of the center of pressure in the foot (apCoP) in post-stroke gait rehabilitation.
results_summary: The apCoP increased significantly between tests, and changes in apCoP were predictive of improvements in walking speed and asymmetry of the single support phase during post-stroke rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Forty-two subacute post-stroke patients.
study_duration: Measurements taken twice with a time interval of more than 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining diet and exercise (including walking) could improve metabolic syndrome (MS) markers compared to diet alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining diet and exercise (including walking) led to statistically significant improvements in heart rate, blood pressure, BMI, blood tests, and walking test performance, while diet alone only improved waist circumference and waist-hip ratio.
population_specificity: 100 volunteers with metabolic syndrome (no overt CVD or diabetes) meeting NCEP/ATP criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review walking impairment in patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS), focusing on gait assessment methods and rehabilitation strategies to improve walking function.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of gait assessment using validated clinical measures like the T25FW and 10MWT for speed and the 2MWT and 6MWT for distance. It also discusses pharmacological and non-pharmacological rehabilitation approaches, including exercise and novel strategies like motor imagery, to restore walking function in MS patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Multiple Sclerosis (pwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Qigong on motor symptoms, walking ability, and balance in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Qigong significantly improved motor symptoms, walking ability, and balance in Parkinson's disease patients, supporting its use as a beneficial alternative therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (180 males and 145 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the safety, feasibility, and effectiveness of supervised exercise training (including walking) as early follow-up treatment for CTEPH patients after pulmonary endarterectomy.
results_summary: The study found that supervised exercise training, including walking, was well-tolerated without severe side effects and significantly improved haemodynamics, 6-minute walking distance, quality of life, and oxygen saturation in CTEPH patients post-PEA. Improvements were observed both shortly after surgery and during the 19-week rehabilitation program.
population_specificity: Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) patients who underwent pulmonary endarterectomy (PEA) (49% female, mean age 57.6 ± 12.4 years, 60% WHO functional class III).
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised exercise training as part of a 19-week rehabilitation program).
study_duration: 19 weeks (3 weeks inpatient, 16 weeks at home).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of breaking up prolonged sitting with light-intensity walking on cardiometabolic health and cognitive performance under conditions of sleep restriction and circadian disruption.
results_summary: The study protocol involves participants completing 3-minute bouts of light-intensity walking every 30 minutes during simulated work shifts, but results are not yet available as the study is in the pre-results stage.
population_specificity: 208 males and females undergoing simulated shiftwork conditions.
effective_dosage: 3-minute bouts of light-intensity walking every 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of recreational therapy programs, including walking, in improving mobility outcomes (e.g., balance, functional performance, fall incidence) for older adults in long-term care.
results_summary: The study found that walking, along with other recreational activities like tai chi and dancing, improved flexibility, functional mobility, and balance in older adults, with strong to moderate evidence from randomized controlled studies. Program implementation was facilitated by clear instruction, encouragement, and minimal equipment.
population_specificity: Older adults in long-term care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lidocaine iontophoresis combined with exercises improves gait and reduces spasticity in children with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in gait speed, stride length, cadence, cycle time, and H/M ratio compared to the control group, indicating enhanced gait parameters and reduced spasticity.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-6 years with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: 2% lidocaine iontophoresis for 20 minutes (1mA/min) immediately before exercises, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different mobility aids (walker, crutches, wheeled knee walker) influence peak and cumulative plantar forces on the stance foot during walking.
results_summary: The wheeled knee walker (WKW) reduced peak net forces compared to walker or control conditions, while crutches had similar peak forces as normal walking. The walker lowered forefoot forces but required more steps, and crutches showed increased peak net and forefoot forces over time.
population_specificity: Twenty-one older adults.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking conditions were tested, not a dosage).
study_duration: Single 200 m walking trial per condition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and potential effectiveness of high-frequency rTMS combined with active cycling for improving lower extremity motor function and spasticity in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that real rTMS treatment significantly improved lower extremity motor function and spasticity compared to sham treatment, but did not show advantages in walking speed or endurance. No serious adverse effects were reported, though mild side effects like dizziness and muscle twitches occurred in some participants.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with first-ever stroke (n=12).
effective_dosage: 11 sessions of HF-rTMS (40 2s-trains of 20 Hz at 90% resting leg motor threshold, later reduced to 80% in some participants).
study_duration: Three weeks per treatment arm, with a four-week washout period between real and sham treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of high-intensity functional training (HIFT), walking at 60% of heart rate reserve, and inactivity on cognitive performance.
results_summary: Walking (WALK) did not significantly improve cognitive performance compared to inactivity (CON) in most tests, while HIFT showed superior improvements in working memory tasks. No differences were found for the Trail Making Test between groups.
population_specificity: 35 healthy individuals (26.7 ± 3.6 years, 18 females).
effective_dosage: Walking at 60% of heart rate reserve for 15 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify new assessment tools for sitting in patients with neurological and neuromuscular conditions, not walking.
results_summary: The review identified the Function in Sitting Test as a promising assessment tool for stroke and multiple sclerosis patients, showing high internal consistency, but found no evidence for brain injury or muscular dystrophy patients.
population_specificity: Adults with neurological conditions (stroke, spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect and safety of combination therapies (electroacupuncture or transcranial direct current stimulation with computerized cognitive rehabilitation treatment) in patients with vascular cognitive impairment, not specifically Walking.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific findings related to Walking, as the study focuses on cognitive rehabilitation therapies for vascular cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: Patients with cognitive impairment caused by stroke after 3 months of onset (n=45).
study_duration: 8 weeks (3 times per week, totaling 24 sessions).

study_goal: To summarize the last 10 years of literature regarding the effects of whole-body vibration (WBV) on bone in children and determine if WBV increases bone acquisition.
results_summary: WBV appears safe and beneficial for bone mass in some pediatric populations, particularly those with Down syndrome or severe motor disabilities. Positive effects on muscle strength, balance, and walking speed were more conclusive, but evidence for bone mass improvement in well-trained individuals is limited.
population_specificity: Pediatric individuals, especially those with Down syndrome or severe motor disabilities and low bone mass.
study_duration: Longer than 6 months suggested for future studies

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate age-related differences in interlimb coordination during gait in typically developing children and adults.
results_summary: The study found that interlimb coordination altered with increasing age, with different limb pair combinations maturing at different stages, from early childhood to adulthood. Variability in coordination decreased with age, indicating more stable gait patterns in older participants.
population_specificity: 98 typically developing participants divided into five age-groups: preschool children (2.9-5.9 years), children (6.0-9.9 years), pubertal children (10.0-13.9 years), adolescents (14.0-18.9 years), and adults (19.0-35.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare feature selection and classification methods for identifying Parkinson's disease patients from control subjects using smartphone-based accelerometer and gyroscope signals during a 20-step walking test.
results_summary: The study found that the highest accuracy for individual steps was achieved with sequential feature selection (7 features) and Naive Bayes classifier (75.3%), while k Nearest Neighbors provided the most accurate overall subject classification (84.5%). The results suggest smartphone-based monitoring is promising for Parkinson's disease assessment.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients and control subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combined exercise training (including walking) affects inflammatory markers and functional capacity in women with multiple sclerosis, and whether these effects vary by disability status.
results_summary: Combined exercise training significantly reduced hs-CRP and IL-6 while increasing PTX-3 and IFN-ƴ, improved functional capacity (e.g., walking distance), and these benefits were independent of disability status.
population_specificity: 94 women with multiple sclerosis, stratified by disability level (low, moderate, high).
effective_dosage: Exercise program performed ? days/week (frequency unclear from abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors contributing to variability in baseline wheelchair transfer ability and changes in transfer ability over time in patients with spina bifida.
results_summary: Motor level was the predominant factor associated with baseline transfer ability, and changes in transfer ability were linked to corresponding changes in motor level, possibly due to muscle strength changes in the iliopsoas and quadriceps. The study accurately classified changes in transfer ability 82.7% of the time using a combination of factors.
population_specificity: Individuals with spina bifida (ages 5-73, median 13.33 years) who were therapeutic ambulators or nonambulators.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Constraint Induced Movement Therapy (CIMT) and Hand Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy (HABIT) on bimanual coordination and gait control during complex whole-body tasks in children with unilateral spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Both CIMT and HABIT improved whole-body movement control, with HABIT enhancing bimanual coordination during tray carrying and CIMT increasing walking speed and stride length. Both groups showed increased minimum toe clearance after training.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-12 years with congenital hemiplegia (GMFCS I-II, MACS I-II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 3-month exercise intervention on habitual walking speed and other health-related outcomes in older women with osteoporosis and vertebral fractures, 3 months post-intervention.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in habitual walking speed between groups post-intervention, but the exercise group showed statistically significant improvements in balance, muscle strength, mobility, and reduced fear of falling. No differences were observed in health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: 149 community-dwelling Norwegian women aged 65+ with osteoporosis and vertebral fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cerebellar intermittent theta burst stimulation (c-iTBS) combined with vestibular rehabilitation (VR) improves gait and balance in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients more effectively than VR alone.
results_summary: MS patients treated with c-iTBS-VR showed significant improvement in gait and balance (measured by the Tinetti Balance and Gait scale) compared to those receiving sham iTBS-VR. The c-iTBS group also performed better in vestibular-ocular reflex exercises.
population_specificity: 20 hospitalized participants with multiple sclerosis (MS) and gait/balance disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (c-iTBS protocol details not provided in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inhaled cannabis could relieve chronic pain in adults with sickle cell disease (SCD) compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant reduction in pain or pain interference (including walking) with cannabis compared to placebo, except for a minor improvement in mood interference. No differences in adverse effects or opioid use were observed.
population_specificity: Adults with SCD and chronic pain on stable analgesics.
effective_dosage: Vaporized cannabis (4.4% THC to 4.9% CBD) 3 times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of conservative treatment (including walking exercise) versus invasive treatment on self-reported health status and disease-specific quality of life in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Walking exercise as part of conservative treatment improved physical domains of health status and disease-specific quality of life (VQ-6 score) in PAD patients, though less significantly than invasive interventions. Both treatments showed measurable improvements in self-reported outcomes after one year.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC) or critical limb ischemia (CLI) due to peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repeated anodal cerebellar transcranial direct current stimulation (ctDCS) enhances motor learning during split-belt treadmill walking and influences the maintenance of learned walking patterns.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in absolute learning during adaptation between active and sham ctDCS groups, but anodal ctDCS slowed de-adaptation, suggesting it may help maintain therapeutic effects. Secondary analyses revealed significant cumulative and session-specific effects on immediate adaptation and de-adaptation.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy individuals.
effective_dosage: Three consecutive sessions of active or sham anodal ctDCS during split-belt treadmill training.
study_duration: Three consecutive sessions, with outcomes measured one week later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in health-related quality of life, depression, anxiety, and physical activity (including walking) after bariatric surgery in patients with obesity.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in total metabolic equivalent tasks (including walking) or physical activity levels 12 months after bariatric surgery, despite improvements in physical quality of life and depression scores.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity scheduled for bariatric surgery (laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy or gastric bypass) and matched controls in Hong Kong.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a multimodal exercise program (MEP) on gait performance in individuals with dementia (IWD).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvements in gait performance or dual task costs from the MEP. However, subgroup analyses revealed that baseline motor and cognitive performance influenced individual responses, with changes in lower limb strength and cognitive function explaining some variance in gait improvements.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate dementia, aged ≥ 65 years, living in care facilities, and able to walk at least 10 meters.
effective_dosage: Not specified (16-week multimodal exercise program tailored to IWD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) combined with usual care (exercise and orthotic support) improves functional ability and walking performance in patients with plantar fasciitis compared to usual care alone.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in AOFAS-F scores and walking speed over three months, but ESWT did not provide additional benefits over usual care alone. Cadence increased in the ESWT group but declined in the control group by the third month.
population_specificity: Patients with plantar fasciitis (ESWT group: n=23, control group: n=21).
effective_dosage: 2000 shock waves with 0.02 mJ/mm² (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of financial incentives on physical activity, specifically focusing on walking behavior.
results_summary: Financial incentives increased walking behavior (steps walked) during the intervention, with a small sustained improvement even after incentives ceased. No significant changes were observed in total minutes of physical activity or kilocalories expended.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of workplace interventions, including walking groups, to improve dietary, physical activity, and sleep behaviors among school and childcare staff.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with some non-significant improvements in physical activity behaviors (e.g., leisure-time activity) favoring intervention groups, but no consistent statistically significant outcomes. Some outcomes even favored control groups.
population_specificity: School and childcare staff

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of vestibular dysfunction on cognitive and motor performance in a dual-task setting, comparing it to single-task protocols.
results_summary: The study developed a dual-task protocol (2BALANCE) to better represent daily activities, showing potential for improved clinical care by evaluating cognitive-motor interference in vestibular dysfunction patients.
population_specificity: Young adults, persons with bilateral vestibulopathy, and persons with unilateral vestibular loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize pulmonary function and disability status in post-acute COVID-19 patients and propose an early rehabilitation protocol, including walking assessments.
results_summary: Post-acute COVID-19 patients showed severe disability and dyspnea, with only 43.7% able to walk and poor performance in the 6-Minute Walking Test (mean distance: 45.0±100.6 meters). The study proposed an early rehabilitation protocol based on baseline oxygen needs.
population_specificity: Post-acute COVID-19 patients (mean age 72.6±10.9 years) admitted to an Italian Rehabilitation Unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss core priority treatments for osteoarthritis (OA), including walking as part of exercise and physical activity, and evaluate its role in OA care.
results_summary: The study highlights walking as a safe, evidence-based treatment for OA, emphasizing its inclusion in tailored care programs alongside other therapies like weight-loss and education. It supports walking as an effective component for managing OA symptoms and improving well-being.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip and knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of pulmonary rehabilitation (PR), including supervised lower limb endurance training (e.g., walking), on dyspnea and other outcomes in patients with stable COPD.
results_summary: PR significantly improved dyspnea across multiple measures (MRC questionnaire, transitional dyspnea index, Borg score, CRQ dyspnea score) and increased exercise capacity (6-minute walking distance, peak workload, peak VO2).
population_specificity: Patients with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Supervised lower limb endurance training (e.g., walking) as a minimal essential component.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate long-term walking ability and patient satisfaction in Charcot Marie Tooth (CMT) subjects who underwent functional surgery (FS) for foot deformities.
results_summary: The study found that 75% of patients maintained high gait efficiency (WHS ≥ 5), and nearly 80% were satisfied with FS (pGIC ≥ 4). Re-intervention rates decreased significantly over time, and complications were rare (5 cases).
population_specificity: 63 CMT patients (35 women, 28 men; mean age 42) with demyelinating (75%), axonal (20%), or other types (5%) of CMT who underwent FS between 1967 and 2018.
study_duration: Long-term follow-up (assessed between mid-2018 and mid-2019 for surgeries performed from 1967 to 2018).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical value of myocardial work (MW) in assessing therapeutic effects in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), including changes in 6-min walking distance.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in myocardial work between DCM patients and healthy controls, with improvements in global work index and 6-min walking distance post-therapy, though LV ejection fraction and global longitudinal strain did not change significantly.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and 30 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a culturally targeted SMS intervention for promoting walking and physical activity among insufficiently active Latino adults compared to standard telephone advising and a nutrition-focused SMS intervention.
results_summary: The study assessed changes in walking and other physical activity measures at 6, 12, and 18 months, but specific results regarding efficacy were not detailed in the abstract. The primary outcome was 12-month change in walking, with secondary outcomes including other forms of physical activity, physical function, and well-being.
population_specificity: Generally healthy, insufficiently active Latino adults ages 35 and older living in five northern California counties.
study_duration: 12 months (with a subset assessed at 18 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dual-task versus single-task balance training on balance, mobility, cognition, and sleep quality in transfemoral amputees.
results_summary: Both groups improved in balance and mobility, but the dual-task group showed greater improvements in dual-task performance, functional mobility, gait speed, cognition, and sleep quality.
population_specificity: Transfemoral amputees (N=20)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Dalfampridine extended release tablets (D-ER) at 7.5 mg or 10 mg doses could improve post-stroke ambulation, measured by a ≥20% increase in the 2-minute walk test (2 MinWT).
results_summary: The study found no significant treatment effect, with similar improvements in walking distance across placebo, 7.5 mg D-ER, and 10 mg D-ER groups. The proportion of subjects achieving ≥20% improvement on the 2 MinWT was also nonsignificant, leading to early termination of the trial.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with gait impairment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety, feasibility, and effectiveness of blood flow restriction-empowered low-intensity interval walking (BFR-W) versus conventional intensive overground walking (CON-W) in improving gait speed and functional capacity in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and severe gait disabilities.
results_summary: BFR-W was found to be safe, with lower perceived exertion and heart rate compared to CON-W. Both groups showed significant improvements in gait speed, with BFR-W demonstrating greater increases (13% vs. 5%) and more durable clinical benefits. Most secondary outcomes improved in both groups without significant between-group differences.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive MS (Expanded Disability Status Scale 5.5–6.5), aged 58 ± 5 years, including 7 males.
effective_dosage: 12 rehabilitation sessions over 6 weeks (interval walking with BFR bands at the thighs for BFR-W; physiotherapist-assisted overground walking for CON-W).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Sildenafil in treating pulmonary hypertension caused by chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD-PH), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that Sildenafil improved six-minute walking distance (6MWD) and pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PASP) in COPD-PH patients but showed no significant effect on SF-36 or Borg dyspnea index. Adverse reactions were mild and tolerable.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary hypertension caused by chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD-PH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore methods for improving walking function in individuals with spinal cord injury, including the potential of overground robotic exoskeletons and wheelchair skills training.
results_summary: The study suggests that walking function can be improved through practice, training, assistive devices, or stimulation, and highlights the potential of robotic exoskeletons for future mobility. Wheelchair skills training is also noted as beneficial for participation.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury who have residual lower extremity motor control.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH), alone or combined with walking practice, enhances walking recovery in individuals with subacute spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized, placebo-controlled trial to assess AIH's effects on walking recovery, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The hypothesis suggests AIH may harness endogenous plasticity mechanisms to improve walking in both ambulatory and non-ambulatory subacute SCI patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with traumatic, subacute SCI (<12 months post-injury), stratified into non-ambulatory and ambulatory groups.
effective_dosage: Non-ambulatory group: 15 episodes of 90s AIH at 10.0% O₂ per day; ambulatory group: same AIH protocol combined with 30 minutes of walking practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of three different treatment proposals (dry-land therapy, Ai Chi aquatic therapy, and combined therapy) to improve pain, gait, and balance in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The combined therapy group and the experimental group (Ai Chi aquatic therapy) showed significantly better results in improving pain, gait, and balance compared to the dry-land therapy group after twelve weeks of treatment.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (40 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (sessions included walking exercises, trunk mobility, and Ai Chi aquatic therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of bodyweight shifting and lower limb loading exercises during stepping with and without augmented feedback, followed by overground walking, on mobility in ambulatory individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Both training sessions improved mobility, but the session with augmented feedback showed significantly greater improvements in timed up-and-go, walking speed, sit-to-stand performance, and limb loading compared to training without feedback. The findings suggest augmented feedback enhances rehabilitation outcomes.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (post-injury time >6 years).
effective_dosage: 10 minutes per leg of bodyweight shifting and lower limb loading exercises, followed by 10 minutes of overground walking.
study_duration: Single intervention session with a 2-week washout period between conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of valgus knee bracing at different tension levels on external knee adduction moment (KAM) during walking and whether body height modifies these effects.
results_summary: Valgus bracing minimally increased knee flexion and slightly reduced gait velocity but did not significantly reduce KAM measures. However, body height influenced KAM changes, with taller participants showing increased KAM and shorter participants showing decreased KAM at maximal tension.
population_specificity: 32 knee-healthy participants
effective_dosage: Incremental valgus tension levels (zero, normal, maximum tolerable)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a 6-month physical activity program using connected devices could improve health-related quality of life and reduce fatigue in women with metastatic breast cancer.
results_summary: The study proposed an intervention involving activity trackers, walking sessions, and quizzes to evaluate improvements in quality of life and fatigue reduction, with assessments planned at multiple time points up to 18 months.
population_specificity: Women with metastatic breast cancer, at least one positive hormone receptor, and planned first-line chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: At least three weekly walking sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define the clinical characteristics, disease outcomes, and natural history of Multiple Sulfatase Deficiency (MSD) through a systematic literature review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study identified 75 publications with data on 143 MSD patients, finding that less severe mutations, low disease burden, and achievement of independent walking positively correlated with longer survival. The mean survival was 13 years, with the nervous, skeletal, and integumentary systems most frequently affected.
population_specificity: Individuals with Multiple Sulfatase Deficiency (MSD), a rare lysosomal storage disorder caused by SUMF1 mutations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify common neurological impairments, including walking/gait abnormalities, and review biomedical technologies that could assist or rehabilitate these impairments.
results_summary: The study identified walking/gait abnormality as one of the most general motor impairments and found that 22 biomedical technologies could compensate or rehabilitate neurological impairments, including those affecting walking.
population_specificity: Neurological patients with various impairments, including walking/gait abnormalities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of walking versus lying on preventing hypotension requiring treatment in women undergoing spinal anesthesia for caesarean section.
results_summary: The study found no clear difference between walking and lying groups in preventing hypotension requiring treatment (RR 0.71, 95% CI 0.41 to 1.21), based on very low-quality evidence from a single small study.
population_specificity: Women undergoing spinal anesthesia for caesarean section.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify elements that maintain high physical activity levels and prevent a decrease in walking steps during a 9-week mHealth intervention for Japanese salespersons.
results_summary: The study found that behavioral characteristics (e.g., consistent step recording) positively correlated with average walking steps, while team characteristics (e.g., regular communication and smaller team size) helped prevent a decrease in walking steps over time.
population_specificity: Japanese salespersons from 11 companies.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step data recorded via smartphone apps).

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of a practitioner-led, peer-group sports intervention for children with CP at GMFCS Level I-II.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide sufficient information to summarize the study's findings regarding Walking's effects.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (GMFCS I-II; aged 6-12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and validate real-life gait markers for degenerative cerebellar disease using wearable sensors to assess ataxic gait changes.
results_summary: The study identified gait variability measures (lateral step deviation and spatial step variability) that effectively distinguished patients from controls with high accuracy (0.86) and correlated strongly with clinical ataxia severity (ρ = 0.76), demonstrating sensitivity to small differences in disease severity.
population_specificity: 43 patients with degenerative cerebellar disease (SARA 9.4 ± 3.9) and 35 controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the phenotypic effects of NEXMIF gene mutations, including developmental delays and walking age in affected individuals.
results_summary: The study found that males with NEXMIF mutations exhibited increasingly delayed walking age, among other severe intellectual and developmental impairments, while females showed milder intellectual disability but higher incidence of drug-resistant epilepsy.
population_specificity: Patients with pathogenic NEXMIF variants, including 45 cases (24 symptomatic females) from an Indian family and previously published reports.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how upper extremity immobilization and walking speed affect spatiotemporal gait parameters in stroke patients with hemiparesis.
results_summary: The study found that immobilizing upper extremities significantly altered stride length, step width, velocity, and step length on the paretic side at self-selected walking speeds, but not during fast walking. The results suggest that upper extremity movement may be important for gait rehabilitation in stroke patients.
population_specificity: 29 stroke patients with hemiparesis.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait patterns assessed, not a dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of antigravity treadmill (AGT) combined with conventional rehabilitation (CR) versus CR alone in patients with sarcopenia after hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: Both groups showed improvement, but the AGT+CR group demonstrated additional benefits in walking ability (KOVAL scores), functional ambulation (FAC), and balance (BBS) at various follow-up intervals, with statistically significant differences.
population_specificity: Patients with sarcopenia after hip fracture surgery (n=45).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether an internet-based physical activity and exercise promotion program could maintain the benefits of inpatient rehabilitation (reduced fatigue, improved quality of life, and gait) in persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found that fatigue decreased in both groups after rehabilitation but increased again in the control group (CG) at 3 and 6 months post-rehabilitation, while the intervention group (IG) maintained improvements. The internet-based program effectively conserved the rehabilitation benefits for fatigue, quality of life, and gait in PwMS.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) with an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) ≤ 6.0 and fatigue (WEIMuS ≥ 32).
effective_dosage: Not specified (internet-based physical activity promotion program for 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between rehabilitative exercise outcomes (specifically walking interventions) and plasma levels of hemostasis inhibitors in patients with progressive multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that rehabilitative walking programs moderately modified plasma levels of hemostasis inhibitors, with higher baseline protein S levels associated with improved gait speed. Patients with decreased tissue factor pathway inhibitor (TFPI) levels showed significant functional recovery, particularly after robot-assisted gait training (RAGT).
population_specificity: Sixty-one severely disabled progressive multiple sclerosis (P-MS) patients.
effective_dosage: 12 walking sessions of either robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) or conventional overground therapy (CT).
study_duration: The intervention lasted until the completion of 12 sessions, with follow-up at 3 months post-rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of fresh whole blood (FWB) from Walking Blood Banks for resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage, particularly in isolated or crisis settings.
results_summary: The study found that survival rates were equivalent between FWB and non-FWB groups, even though FWB patients were more severely injured. However, evidence was scarce and of low quality, with potential underestimation of adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with life-threatening hemorrhage, particularly in isolated communities or during crises like the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of using a prompting device to reduce sedentary behavior with light walking and examine its effects on cognitive function, physical function, and quality of life in older adults with mild to moderate cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved cognitive function, physical function, and quality of life, with high adherence (over 70% completed >80% of prescribed activity bouts) and no dropouts.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 86.7) with mild to moderate cognitive impairment residing in assisted living.
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of light walking three times a day after meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effectiveness of Nordic walking (NW) on cardiovascular performance and quality of life in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) compared to a conventional cardiovascular rehabilitation (CCVR) program.
results_summary: NW led to higher cardiovascular and functional performance compared to CCVR, with improvements in exercise ergometry, metabolic equivalent of tasks, and the Six-Minute Walking Test, but no significant differences in ejection fraction or quality of life measures.
population_specificity: 83 CAD patients (59.1±7.0 years)
effective_dosage: 40 minutes of walking four times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify current sensor-based approaches for measuring walking behavior in paraplegic patients and integrate this data with a medical register.
