results_summary: The study reviewed 287 publications and identified key categories of sensor use, with "FES / neuroprosthesis control" being the most researched, followed by "assessment of physical activity."
population_specificity: Patients with paraplegia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and potential effectiveness of a 12-week progressive, multicomponent home-based exercise program (including walking) in improving physical function and frailty status in prefrail and frail older adults with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study focused on feasibility outcomes (recruitment, adherence, attrition) and secondary measures (physical function, frailty status, HRQOL), but efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract. The intervention included walking as part of a tailored exercise program with weekly progression guidance.
population_specificity: Prefrail or frail older adults with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (tailored 12-week exercise program including walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the electromyographic (EMG) features of temporal gait asymmetry (TGA) in post-stroke individuals to understand underlying physiological mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that post-stroke individuals with TGA exhibited altered muscle activation patterns, particularly in plantarflexor and dorsiflexor timing during gait, compared to symmetric and normative controls. These findings suggest neuromuscular impairments or compensations affecting locomotor coordination.
population_specificity: Post-stroke individuals with or without temporal gait asymmetry (TGA) and control adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to diagnose and describe a rare case of recurrent diabetic myonecrosis in a patient with long-standing diabetes, presenting with difficulty in walking.
results_summary: The study identified recurrent diabetic myonecrosis in a patient with bilateral thigh pain and walking difficulty, confirmed by MRI and histopathology, and treated with bed rest, opioids, and aspirin.
population_specificity: A 59-year-old male with ten years of diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether oral sodium bicarbonate improves physical function, quality of life, and other health markers in older people with chronic kidney disease and mild acidosis.
results_summary: The study found that oral sodium bicarbonate did not improve physical function, quality of life, kidney function, bone health, or blood vessel health compared to placebo. More participants in the sodium bicarbonate group experienced side effects, though blood pressure remained similar between groups.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥60 years with advanced chronic kidney disease (glomerular filtration rate category 4 or 5, not on dialysis) and mild acidosis (serum bicarbonate concentration <22 mmol/l).
effective_dosage: Started at 500 mg three times daily, increasing to 1 g three times daily if serum bicarbonate remained <22 mmol/l at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a telephone-guided graduated walking program could improve muscle mass in rectal cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that prehabilitation, including a walking program, improved muscle mass in rectal cancer patients receiving NACRT, suggesting potential benefits for mitigating poor outcomes linked to low muscle mass.
population_specificity: Rectal cancer patients (mean age 66.8 years, 64% male, 98% white) scheduled for neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy and surgery.
effective_dosage: 13-17-week telephone-guided graduated walking program (specific frequency/intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current evidence base for the clinical efficacy of three-dimensional instrumented gait analysis (3DGA) in studying human walking.
results_summary: The study found that 3DGA changes treatment plans, increases clinicians' confidence in decisions, and improves agreement among clinicians. Patient outcomes improved when 3DGA data were available and followed, with a notable reduction in severe crouch gait incidence from 25% to 4% after practice changes including 3DGA.
population_specificity: Individuals with gait pathology (specific conditions not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of change in patient willingness to undergo total knee arthroplasty (TKA), focusing on factors like income and expected difficulty with postoperative walking.
results_summary: Higher income and anticipated difficulty walking postoperatively were significantly associated with increased willingness to have TKA, while general health, race, and recent knee injections approached significance.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at high risk for developing knee osteoarthritis from the Osteoarthritis Initiative (OAI).
study_duration: Not specified (longitudinal analysis of baseline and follow-up data)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein supplementation could reduce exercise-induced muscle damage and soreness in older adults after prolonged moderate-intensity walking.
results_summary: The study found that protein supplementation did not reduce muscle damage, soreness, or fatigue in older adults after prolonged walking. No significant differences were observed between the protein and placebo groups in terms of muscle recovery.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years, 81% male)
effective_dosage: Not specified (protein or placebo supplement during breakfast and post-exercise)
study_duration: Three consecutive days (30/40/50 km walking per day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess daily walking distance levels in adolescents with idiopathic scoliosis (AIS), comparing those treated with a night brace, untreated AIS patients, and a control group.
results_summary: The study found that AIS patients treated with a night brace walked significantly more (3.65–3.70 km/day) than untreated AIS patients (2.31–2.40 km/day) and controls (2.58–2.60 km/day). No restriction in daily walking distance was observed between adolescents without scoliosis and those with idiopathic scoliosis.
population_specificity: Adolescents with idiopathic scoliosis (AIS) (n=19, aged 13–17) and asymptomatic controls (n=25, aged 12–14).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking distance measured, not prescribed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand fampridine-induced changes in gait kinetics and their association with improved walking performance in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: PR-fampridine significantly improved walking speed and endurance in patients with multiple sclerosis, with notable changes in gait kinetics observed in a responsive sub-group. These kinetic changes correlated with superior clinical walking performance under PR-fampridine.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (n = 44 for kinetic analysis, n = 61 overall).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and synthesize qualitative literature on the patient experience of gout flares, including their impact on walking and other daily activities, to inform the development of flare-specific outcome measures.
results_summary: The study identified that gout flares significantly impact walking and other daily activities, alongside broader physical, psychological, and social effects. These findings highlight the need for more comprehensive outcome measures in clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing gout flares

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic factors for changes in the timed 4-stair climb (4SC) assessment in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients and evaluate their utility in clinical trial design.
results_summary: The study found that combining measures of ambulatory function, height, and weight significantly improved prognostic accuracy for 1-year changes in 4SC performance. Prognostic score adjustment could reduce clinical trial sample size requirements by approximately 40%.
population_specificity: Patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) from a phase 3 trial and two real-world sources.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of land walking (LW) and water walking (WW) on peripheral artery endothelial function in older sedentary individuals.
results_summary: The study found that 6 months of LW significantly improved brachial artery endothelial function (flow-mediated dilation) compared to the control group, while WW did not show significant differences. No changes were observed in smooth muscle cell function (glyceryl trinitrate response) in any group.
population_specificity: Sedentary older individuals (mean age 61.9 ± 6.6 years, 23.5% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety, reliability, and feasibility of using the ReWalk ReStore™ soft robotic exosuit for post-stroke gait rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that the ReStore™ was safe and reliable, with no device-related falls or serious adverse events. Participants increased both device-assisted and unassisted maximum walking speeds after five days of training.
population_specificity: 44 users with post-stroke hemiparesis.
effective_dosage: Up to 5 days of training with the device on treadmill and over ground.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treadmill training with intense, unpredictable perturbations improves dynamic balance and gait post-stroke more effectively than treadmill walking-only training.
results_summary: Perturbation training led to significant improvements in balance, gait, balance confidence, and community integration, while walking-only training had minimal effects except on balance confidence. The benefits persisted at follow-up, and satisfaction with perturbation training was high.
population_specificity: Individuals post-stroke with reduced dynamic balance abilities, able to walk on a treadmill without support for at least 1 minute.
effective_dosage: Nine training sessions over 3 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of two surgical approaches (PLA and DLA) for hemiarthroplasty in femoral neck fractures, focusing on patient-relevant outcomes like walking ability, pain, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found mixed results: PLA was associated with more dislocations but fewer walking problems and less abductor insufficiency compared to DLA. Patients with PLA tended to have better quality of life, less pain, and higher satisfaction.
population_specificity: Patients with femoral neck fractures undergoing hemiarthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a group motivational plus implementation intentions intervention in promoting adherence to an unsupervised walking program for fibromyalgia patients, compared to other conditions.
results_summary: In the short-term, adherence to the minimum and standard walking program (primary outcomes) was influenced by time, but long-term results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 157 women with fibromyalgia.
study_duration: Measures taken at baseline, short-term (7 weeks post-intervention), mid-term (12 weeks), and long-term (36 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of trunk training for improving gait and trunk kinematics in stroke patients and identify variables explaining mobility carryover effects.
results_summary: Trunk training significantly improved trunk control, gait parameters (speed, step length, step width), and center-of-mass excursions compared to cognitive training. Anteroposterior trunk movements explained 30% of mobility carryover effects, but lower limb kinematics showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (n=39, trunk training group=19, cognitive training group=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an innovative rehabilitation treatment combining traditional therapy with technological devices (TYMO system and Walker View) for improving balance, gait performance, and reducing fall risk in elderly patients with hip fractures.
results_summary: The study compared traditional rehabilitation with two enhanced approaches (traditional plus TYMO or Walker View) but did not report specific outcome results in the abstract. The primary outcomes measured were risk of falling, gait performance, and fear of falling, with assessments at multiple follow-up points.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (aged unspecified) with hip fractures, hospitalized 4 weeks prior to study initiation.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of traditional therapy plus 20 minutes with a technological device (intervention group) or 50 minutes of traditional therapy (control group), 3 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Pavlik harness treatment versus active surveillance in improving acetabular development in infants with stable dysplastic hips.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in acetabular development between the Pavlik harness group and the active surveillance group at 6, 10, and 18 months of age, suggesting that observation may be preferable to treatment for stable dysplastic hips.
population_specificity: Infants aged 3 to 4 months with stable dysplastic hips.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (treatment involved Pavlik harness use, not a dosage).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 6, 12 weeks, 10 months, and walking age (after 18 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether locomotor training provides a sufficiently intense stimulus to improve fitness or health in people with spinal cord injury, beyond just functional walking ability.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that locomotor training, particularly with powered exoskeletons, improves accessibility and community ambulation but does not conclusively answer whether it sufficiently challenges cardiovascular, muscular, or metabolic systems to be considered viable exercise. The review will summarize existing literature on this topic.
population_specificity: People with spinal cord injury (SCI) who are wheelchair-dependent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of intrathecal nusinersen on motor function and supportive care needs in children with SMA types 1 and 2 after one year of treatment.
results_summary: The study found improved motor function scores in children under and over 2 years of age, but no child achieved walking. Patients required increased nutritional and ventilatory support despite motor improvements.
population_specificity: Children with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) types 1 and 2 in France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of adhesive glue versus conventional suturing for first-degree perineal tear repair, focusing on pain scores, wound complications, and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: The skin adhesive group had significantly lower pain scores during walking and other activities in the first week post-delivery and became pain-free faster (3.18 vs. 8.65 days) compared to the suture group.
population_specificity: 121 women with first-degree perineal tears post-delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Nordic Walking versus regular Walking on motor and non-motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Both Nordic Walking and regular Walking improved motor and non-motor symptoms, including balance, fatigue, anxiety, and quality of life, but Nordic Walking was not superior to regular Walking.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients at Hoehn and Yahr stages 2-3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enhanced beta-band oscillations in the sensorimotor area could serve as biomarkers for gait recovery in spinal cord injury (SCI) patients and whether tDCS combined with robotic-assisted gait training (RAGT) could modulate these oscillations to improve gait function.
results_summary: The study found that anodal tDCS combined with RAGT modulated high-beta EEG oscillations, enhancing gait recovery. Higher baseline high-beta power predicted better gait function and recovery, while decreases in relative high-beta power during walking were associated with improved recovery.
population_specificity: Thirty-nine patients with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of anodal tDCS over the primary motor area combined with RAGT, 30 sessions total.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of resistance training on recovery in stroke patients through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training may be beneficial for stroke recovery, but the evidence is insufficient for evidence-based rehabilitation. Overall, 30 trials were included, but the abstract does not provide detailed results on Walking specifically.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate clinical characteristics, outcomes, and predictors of survival in patients with congenital heart disease-associated pulmonary artery hypertension (CHD-PAH), including the role of noninvasive parameters like 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found that high-risk baseline 6MWD was a significant predictor of survival in CHD-PAH patients. Noninvasive parameters (functional class, 6MWD, NT-pro BNP/BNP) reliably predicted survival rates.
population_specificity: Patients with congenital heart disease-associated pulmonary artery hypertension (CHD-PAH), mean age 37.4 years, male to female ratio 60:27.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 16-week aerobic exercise training (walking) on sedentary time, light-intensity physical activity (LPA), moderate- to vigorous-intensity physical activity (MVPA), and step numbers in older women.
results_summary: The study found that sedentary time decreased by approximately 39 minutes per day, LPA increased by 19 minutes per day, and MVPA time increased, primarily due to supervised exercise. Daily steps increased more in the moderate-dose group than the low-dose group, with individual differences observed in these changes.
population_specificity: Inactive older women (n = 61; age = 65.5 ± 4.3 years).
effective_dosage: Low dose (33.6 kJ·kg body weight per week) and moderate dose (58.8 kJ·kg body weight per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the immediate effect of manual fascial manipulation on walking pain and ankle dorsiflexion range within the first 4 days after ankle trauma.
results_summary: After one treatment session, 13 of 19 subjects were walking pain-free, and 3 had only minor pain. Ankle dorsiflexion improved significantly by a mean of 7.9° (±5.8°), with most pain-free subjects showing at least 4° increased dorsiflexion.
population_specificity: 19 subjects (5 female, 14 male) with grade I-III ankle sprains.
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed within 4 days post-trauma.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of Baduanjin exercise on cardiopulmonary function and quality of life in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 31 randomized controlled trials showed that Baduanjin exercise combined with other treatments improved exercise capacity (6-minute walking distance), pulmonary function, and quality of life in COPD patients.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients (3045 participants across 31 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) on walking abilities and respiratory function in adult patients with Pompe disease.
results_summary: The study found that ERT initially improved walking distance (1.4% per year) but showed a progressive decline (-2.3% per year) after 2.2 years. Respiratory function (FVC) declined steadily (-0.9% per year), while MEP remained stable.
population_specificity: Adult patients with Pompe disease (n=158) from the French Pompe Registry.
study_duration: Follow-up duration varied, with longitudinal analyses spanning multiple years (cut-off point at 2.2 years for 6MWT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of backward treadmill training (BTT) versus standard forward treadmill training (FTT) on motor impairment in chronic stroke patients receiving botulinum toxin type A therapy.
results_summary: BTT showed significantly greater improvement in gait (10-meter Walking Test) and balance (stabilometric assessment) compared to FTT when used as an adjunct to botulinum toxin therapy in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=18)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neural changes in stroke patients after robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) and compare the effects of early versus late initiation of RAGT.
results_summary: RAGT significantly reorganizes the non-lesioned hemisphere compared to conventional physiotherapy, and early initiation of RAGT accelerates bi-hemispheric reorganization in motor-related brain regions.
population_specificity: Eleven patients with hemiplegia after stroke undergoing inpatient rehabilitation within 3 months of stroke onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the uptake of an app-based supplemental exercise programme in rehabilitation and its effect on length of stay and functional outcomes compared to usual care physiotherapy.
results_summary: The intervention group performed a small supplementary exercise dose (7 minutes or 49 repetitions daily) but showed no differences in length of stay or functional outcomes (walking speed, endurance, mobility, disability) compared to usual care.
population_specificity: 144 individuals with mixed diagnoses (orthopaedic, neurological, reconditioning) admitted for inpatient sub-acute rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: 7 minutes (SD: 9) or 49 repetitions (SD: 48) of supplementary exercise daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of Pilates intervention programs on various health parameters, including walking, in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The majority of studies showed positive results, concluding that Pilates is effective for improving walking, balance, strength, and other physical parameters in MS patients. The intervention was deemed safe and beneficial for rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the motor and non-motor outcomes of Nordic Walking (NW) in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) through a systematic review of existing studies.
results_summary: NW was found to improve symptom severity, walking speed, and gait pattern during the ON-phases of pharmacotherapy, with benefits less consistent during OFF-phases and follow-up without regular training. NW was well accepted and relatively safe, with no significant adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: Patients at early stages of Parkinson's disease with low to moderate severity (318 participants across 13 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and cost advantage of TeGeCoach, a 12-month home-based exercise programme, compared to usual care for improving walking ability in PAD patients.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that TeGeCoach improves walking impairment and reduces healthcare resource use, but results are pending as the trial is pre-results. Primary outcomes focus on patient-reported walking ability, with secondary measures including quality of life and health behavior.
population_specificity: 1760 patients diagnosed with PAD at Fontaine stage II.
effective_dosage: Telemonitored intermittent walking exercise with medical supervision and telephone health coaching (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of underwater gait training versus overground gait training in improving balance and gait function in severe stroke patients.
results_summary: Both underwater and overground gait training improved balance (center of pressure path length and velocity), but underwater training showed less improvement in gait function (step length difference) compared to overground training.
population_specificity: 21 patients with severe hemiplegic stroke
effective_dosage: 30 minutes twice a week for 12 weeks (in addition to 60-minute general physical therapy sessions 5 times a week)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Anluohuaxian Pill in treating pulmonary fibrosis in severe COVID-19 patients, not Walking.
results_summary: The abstract does not report any results related to Walking, as the study focuses on Anluohuaxian Pill for pulmonary fibrosis in COVID-19 patients.
population_specificity: Severe COVID-19 patients (aged 18-80) with pulmonary fibrosis, excluding those with other severe systemic diseases or recent use of anti-fibrotic drugs.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (study focuses on Anluohuaxian Pill, not Walking).
interactions: None mentioned (study does not address Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between clinical and radiological outcomes following oblique lateral interbody fusion (OLIF) in patients with degenerative lumbar diseases, focusing on improvements in walking ability and pain relief.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in clinical scores and radiological parameters post-OLIF, with restoration of foraminal height correlating with better walking ability and reduced lower-extremity pain. However, cage subsidence occurred in 31.7% of patients by 1 year, which was associated with poorer clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: 41 patients with degenerative lumbar diseases, including spondylolisthesis and spinal stenosis with disk height loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical and functional measures related to fall risk in patients with end-stage knee osteoarthritis awaiting total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that greater low back pain and worse walking endurance (measured by the six-minute walk test) were associated with a higher risk of falling in this population. For every 10-meter increase in walking distance, there was a 3.8% reduction in fall risk.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage knee osteoarthritis awaiting total knee arthroplasty (n=259).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted 2-4 weeks prior to surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and adverse events of nonpharmacologic interventions, including walking-related exercises, in patients with exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found that resistance training, pulmonary rehabilitation, whole body vibration, and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation improved 6-minute walking test distance and quality of life in COPD patients. Oxygen titration with a target saturation of 88% to 92% was associated with reduced mortality.
population_specificity: Adults hospitalized for exacerbation of COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oxidative stress markers (MDA and TAC) influence the magnitude of weight loss induced by aerobic exercise (walking/running) in sedentary overweight or obese individuals.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant reductions in fat mass, total body mass, BMI, and fat percentage, along with increased MDA levels, but no changes in TAC. No correlation was found between oxidative stress markers and weight loss outcomes.
population_specificity: Sedentary overweight or obese adults (N=75).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if applying intermittent vibrational cutaneous stimulation during walking could reduce knee pain and improve gait parameters in patients with knee pathologies.
results_summary: Active Treatment A significantly improved patient-reported outcomes and gait measures (knee flexion moment/angle), with changes correlated to reduced pain, while passive Treatment B showed no significant effects.
population_specificity: Thirty-two patients with knee pathologies (injury or disease).
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment, with a 2-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the diagnostic process for functional gait disorders by identifying supportive gait signs and clinical tests to detect inconsistencies and incongruencies.
results_summary: The study identified seven groups of supportive gait signs indicative of functional gait disorders and highlighted clinical tests to reveal inconsistencies and incongruencies, aiding diagnosis. Functional and organic gait disorders may coexist, complicating diagnosis.
population_specificity: Individuals with functional gait disorders (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the measurement properties of constant work rate cycle ergometry (CWRCE) and the endurance shuttle walking test (ESWT) in assessing exercise tolerance in COPD patients.
results_summary: Both CWRCE and ESWT were reliable and responsive to bronchodilation, though symptom limitations differed—more patients reported breathing discomfort during ESWT and leg discomfort during CWRCE. The tests performed well in a multicenter clinical trial, suggesting their suitability depending on study requirements.
population_specificity: 151 patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
effective_dosage: Tiotropium/olodaterol (T/O) 2.5/5 μg or 5/5 μg once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sensorimotor and gait training on proprioception, nerve function, and muscle activation in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
results_summary: The study found that sensorimotor and gait training significantly improved proprioception, nerve conduction velocity, and muscle activation in the lower limbs and multifidus during postural control and walking in DPN patients. The intervention group showed better outcomes compared to the control group, which received only diabetes and foot care education.
population_specificity: Thirty-eight participants (25 male, 13 female) with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
effective_dosage: Sensorimotor and gait training for 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether blood donation (as part of a walking blood bank) negatively impacts battlefield performance in combatants.
results_summary: The study found no clinically or statistically significant differences in cognitive, physical, or shooting performance between combatants who donated blood and those who did not, suggesting blood donation does not impair combat performance.
population_specificity: Israel Defense Forces combatants (military personnel).
effective_dosage: Not specified (standard blood donation volume implied).
study_duration: Single blood donation with follow-up evaluations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a 3-month mobile app-based behavior change program (TravelVu Plus) in promoting active transportation (walking and cycling) and increasing moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA).
results_summary: The study found no immediate effect on MVPA at 3 months, but a delayed improvement of 6.05 minutes per day at 6 months, with a 98% probability of any effect and a 63% probability of exceeding 5 minutes per day. This suggests the app-based intervention had a relevant, though delayed, impact on physical activity.
population_specificity: 254 adults aged 20-65 years from Stockholm County with smartphone access.
study_duration: 3-month behavior change program, with outcomes measured at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of nonoperative treatment protocols on union rate and functional outcomes in patients with acute fifth metatarsal tuberosity fractures.
results_summary: Most acute fifth metatarsal tuberosity fractures healed well with nonoperative treatment, showing good-to-excellent functional outcomes. The nonunion rate was low (1.1%), and short-term results were favorable across different treatment approaches.
population_specificity: Patients with acute fifth metatarsal tuberosity fractures (mean age 42 years, range 27-56).
effective_dosage: 2 to 3 weeks of immobilization in a walking cast, followed by gradual activity increase.
study_duration: Until clinical union was achieved (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sit-to-stand exercises combined with a protein-rich oral nutritional supplement on physical function, nutritional status, and body composition in nursing home residents.
results_summary: The 12-week intervention did not improve physical function but increased body weight. High adherence to the intervention was associated with maintained or improved physical function and a gain in fat-free mass.
population_specificity: Nursing home residents aged ≥75 years, able to rise from a seated position, residing in dementia and somatic care units.
effective_dosage: Sit-to-stand exercises (4 times/day) and oral nutritional supplement (2 bottles/day providing 600 kcal and 36 g protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize risk factors and natural history of accelerated knee osteoarthritis (AKOA) compared to typical osteoarthritis, focusing on joint deterioration and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that AKOA progresses rapidly, often within 12 months, with risk factors including older age, higher BMI, joint misalignment, and pre-existing structural damage. People with AKOA often experience rapid cartilage loss, meniscal tears, and increased joint symptoms, leading to higher rates of knee replacement.
population_specificity: Adults with incident knee osteoarthritis, particularly those at risk for accelerated progression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical significance of balance training in degenerative cerebellar disease and analyze inconsistencies in published data regarding its benefits.
results_summary: Most studies showed statistical and clinically significant improvements in ataxia severity, with some improvements in gait speed and balance measures, though balance improvements did not meet clinical significance criteria. The extent of benefit depended on the balance challenge and training frequency.
population_specificity: Individuals with degenerative cerebellar disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) supplementation in stabilizing clinical symptoms in patients with spastic ataxia of Charlevoix-Saguenay due to SACS gene mutations.
results_summary: DHA was found to be safe and well-tolerated over a 20-month period, with both patients showing stabilization of clinical symptoms instead of the expected deterioration.
population_specificity: Two siblings with biallelic variants in the SACS gene.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of quantitative gait analysis for decision support in early-stage gait disorders across three clinically relevant scenarios.
results_summary: The study highlights the advantages of standardized gait analysis procedures, identifies typical patterns of pathological gait, and demonstrates how gait modulation under different conditions can aid clinical decision-making.
population_specificity: Individuals with early-stage gait disorders, including gait ataxia, hypokinesia, and those with specific fall tendencies in complex mobility situations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) and a healthy traditional Brazilian diet (DieTBra) on improving sarcopenia indicators (including walking speed) and reducing total body fat in severely obese adults.
results_summary: The study found that DieTBra contributed to improvements in walking speed and handgrip strength, along with reductions in total body fat. The combination of DieTBra and EVOO showed significant benefits in these outcomes.
population_specificity: Severely obese adults (111 participants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how gait characteristics during straight and turning walking phases predict falls in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that gait variables during turns and straight walking similarly predicted falls, with higher swing percent reducing fall risk and higher double support percent increasing fall risk. Swing variability during turns was also associated with increased fall risk.
population_specificity: Community-based older adults (N = 253; mean age 78.5; 51% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the potential benefit of using footwear with optimized cushioning for plantar pressure reduction in people with diabetes and peripheral neuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that patient-specific optimum stiffness reduced peak pressure by 46% on average, while using the same stiffness across all participants lowered pressure reduction by at least 9 percentile points. Optimal stiffness was significantly correlated with BMI, with stiffer materials needed for higher BMI individuals.
population_specificity: Fifteen people with diabetic foot syndrome.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (footwear stiffness was adjusted, not a dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mental practice (MP) improves upper extremity rehabilitation outcomes for individuals living with stroke, focusing on activity, impairment, daily living, quality of life, and adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found moderate-certainty evidence that MP combined with other treatments improves upper extremity activity and impairment post-stroke, but low-certainty evidence suggests no significant improvement in activities of daily living.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors with upper extremity functional deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early robot-assisted gait training (using HAL) could promote neuroplasticity and improve motor function in acute stroke patients by examining microstructural changes in white matter.
results_summary: Both conventional physical therapy (CPT) and HAL gait training improved motor function and independence. HAL training specifically facilitated recovery of inter-hemispheric communication and prevented Wallerian degeneration in the affected pyramidal tract, as evidenced by DTI changes.
population_specificity: Patients with first-ever stroke requiring walking aids, initiating gait training within 1 week of stroke onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine long-term clinical outcomes, including reduced exercise capacity (measured by 6-minute walking distance), in survivors of SARS and MERS after hospitalization or ICU admission.
results_summary: The study found that SARS and MERS survivors commonly experienced reduced exercise capacity, with a mean 6-minute walking distance of 461 m (CI 450–473 m) up to 6 months after discharge. Psychological impairments and lung function abnormalities were also prevalent.
population_specificity: Adult survivors of SARS and MERS who were hospitalized or admitted to the ICU.
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed up to 6 months after discharge and beyond.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to illustrate the fundamentals and applications of functional electrical stimulation (FES) technology for restoring functional movements like walking in paralyzed individuals.
results_summary: The study highlights FES as an effective therapeutic intervention for helping stroke and spinal cord injury patients regain abilities such as standing and walking, with potential for future advancements like integration with brain-computer interfaces and wearable technology.
population_specificity: Individuals with paralysis due to stroke or spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the construct validity of the Gait Assessment and Intervention Tool (GAIT) in assessing gait coordination in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The GAIT showed excellent correlation with the Rivermead Visual Gait Assessment (RVGA) and moderate correlations with other functional mobility measures, but lower correlations with speed-based measures like the Timed Up&Go (TUG) and Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS).
population_specificity: Thirty-five patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of respiratory muscle training on muscle strength, lung function, walking capacity, and respiratory complications in stroke patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed significant improvements in respiratory muscle strength, lung function, walking capacity (6-minute walk test), and reduced respiratory complications in stroke patients undergoing respiratory muscle training compared to no intervention or sham intervention. The benefits persisted for up to 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a rehabilitation program combining whole-body electromyostimulation (WB-EMS) with exercise training improves functional capacity, body mass, and heart rate variability in patients shortly after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The WB-EMS group showed significant improvements in walking distance and BMI compared to the sham group, with both groups demonstrating enhanced heart rate variability. The addition of WB-EMS provided greater functional and BMI benefits but did not further improve HRV beyond exercise alone.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Five exercise training sessions per week over 6 weeks, combined with WB-EMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare motor learning improvements in children with developmental coordination disorder (DCD) between Wii-based training and task-specific training (TST).
results_summary: Both Wii training and TST improved motor learning, with Wii excelling in archery and bowling tasks, while TST showed better results in balance beam and table tennis tasks. Improvements varied based on the type of task trained.
population_specificity: 32 children with developmental coordination disorder (DCD), aged unspecified.
study_duration: 12 sessions (total duration not specified in weeks/months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the physiological and psychological responses to height exposure, including visual height intolerance and acrophobia, and their impact on posture, gait, and eye movements.
results_summary: The study found that visual height intolerance and acrophobia lead to anxious control of postural stability, muscle stiffening, and altered gait patterns, with symptoms saturating at specific heights. Anxiety was identified as a critical factor influencing these responses.
population_specificity: Adults and prepubertal children (aged 8-10 years) with visual height intolerance or acrophobia.

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of outpatient robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) in improving walking abilities in ambulatory children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in walking abilities (measured by GMFM E, GMFM D, or timed walking tests) after RAGT or usual care. The trial was stopped early due to recruitment problems, limiting its conclusions.
population_specificity: Ambulatory children with spastic cerebral palsy (mean age 11.3 years, range 6.0-15.3 years).
study_duration: 5 weeks per intervention (RAGT and usual care).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of pulmonary rehabilitation involving downhill walking training versus conventional level walking training in patients with COPD.
results_summary: Downhill walking induced contractile muscle fatigue with lower dyspnoea and fatigue compared to level walking, suggesting potential benefits for COPD patients undergoing pulmonary rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), aged 62±8 years.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) combined with conventional therapy on standing and walking abilities in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: The study found meaningful improvements in standing and walking abilities (measured by GMFM66-D and -E) in both mild-moderate and severe CP groups. Greater improvements were statistically significant in the mild-moderate group (GMFCS levels I-III) compared to the severe group (levels IV-V).
population_specificity: Children aged 4-18 years with CP (GMFCS levels I-V).
effective_dosage: RAGT (30 min/session) + conventional physiotherapy (30 min/session), 3-4 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of land-walking and water-walking on aerobic fitness in sedentary older individuals and determine if water-walking provides similar fitness benefits as land-walking.
results_summary: Both land-walking and water-walking improved maximal oxygen uptake significantly compared to the control group, with water-walking showing slightly greater improvements. Time to exhaustion increased significantly only in the land-walking group. By 48 weeks, fitness gains returned to near baseline levels in both exercise groups.
population_specificity: Sedentary older individuals.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes per week of moderate-intensity exercise, 3 sessions weekly.
study_duration: 24 weeks of intervention followed by a 24-week no-intervention period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Lithothamnion species, seawater-derived magnesium, and pine bark as alternative nutraceutical treatments for Knee-Osteoarthritis (KOA) compared to glucosamine.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the tested nutraceuticals on KOA, as it is incomplete.
population_specificity: Participants with symptomatic Knee-Osteoarthritis (sKOA) (n = 30).
effective_dosage: Glucosamine group: 2000 mg/day (specific dosage for other treatments not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week exercise program could reduce peak medial tibiofemoral joint contact force during walking in individuals who had undergone medial arthroscopic partial meniscectomy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in peak medial knee loads between the exercise and control groups during normal- or fast-paced walking, though individual variability in muscle activation patterns was observed.
population_specificity: Adults aged 30-50 years who had undergone medial arthroscopic partial meniscectomy within the past 3-12 months.
effective_dosage: 12-week, home-based, physiotherapist-guided exercise program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cognitive rehabilitation (CR) and aerobic exercise (EX), including walking, are effective treatments for cognitive impairment, particularly processing speed deficits, in people with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it hypothesizes that CR and EX, including walking, will improve processing speed and that combining these treatments will be more effective than either alone. The primary outcome is measured by the Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT), with secondary outcomes including memory, depression, walking speed, and MRI-based neural mechanisms.
population_specificity: People with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS) who have objectively identified cognitive impairment.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 12 weeks (specific walking dosage not detailed).
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with assessments at baseline, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of mental simulation practice (MSP) on measures of physical function recovery in patients who underwent lower limb joint replacement surgery.
results_summary: MSP showed significant positive effects on physical function recovery, including improved maximal voluntary strength, brisk walking speed, timed up-to-go test performance, and active flexion of the affected leg compared to standard physical therapy. The effects were significantly predicted by the total number of training sessions.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent primary unilateral knee or hip replacement surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between participant-expressed motivations/barriers and their performance in a pedometer-based walking intervention for dialysis patients.
results_summary: Participants motivated by maintaining/improving functional ability achieved weekly goals more often and increased steps significantly, while health-related barriers reduced overall target achievement and step increases. Environmental or safety concerns were linked to failure in reaching overall targets.
population_specificity: Dialysis patients (n=30)
effective_dosage: Weekly step goals (specific step count not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of different types of ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) on energy expenditure metrics during walking in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that AFOs can immediately improve energy expenditure metrics, such as energy cost and mechanical work, during walking in adults with chronic stroke, but there was insufficient evidence to assess medium-term efficacy or compare different AFO designs.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic stroke (195 participants across 15 trials, mostly in the chronic phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mobile PA app targeting walking behavior in improving lifestyle behaviors and lowering cardiometabolic disease risk in adults with low socioeconomic position.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a cluster-randomized trial combining nudging, pricing, and a mobile PA app, but results on walking behavior changes (steps per day) are pending as the abstract outlines the design rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: Dutch-speaking adults aged 45-75 years with low socioeconomic position who purchase more than half of their household groceries at selected supermarkets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate differences in cardiac response between patients with high and low improvements in functional capacity following cardiac rehabilitation (CR) using a 6-minute walking test (6MWT) and wearable ECG technology.
results_summary: All patients improved in functional capacity during CR, with differences in heart rate parameters and digital biomarkers observed between high- and low-response groups, suggesting potential for personalized treatment strategies.
population_specificity: 129 patients undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (6-minute walking test performed at baseline and four follow-ups).
study_duration: Duration of CR program not explicitly stated (follow-up tests conducted during the program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic factors affecting outcomes in acute traumatic spinal cord injury (tSCI) and provide recommendations for improving recovery, including the ability to walk.
results_summary: The study found that initial neurologic examination, early surgical decompression, and maintaining mean arterial pressure >85 for 7 days significantly improve neurologic outcomes, including walking ability, in tSCI patients. Biomarkers and MRI also showed predictive value for recovery.
population_specificity: Patients with acute traumatic spinal cord injury (tSCI).
